title: Is it me or are most non-english speaking flamers Chinese?
body: I swear, most Chinese players I come across who can't speak English flame you in their own language. The amount of Non-English chinese people that flame you while going 0-10 is ridiculous.

replies.body: Yeah I would like to agree with you but apparently that's racist and it will just get the post removed

don't really see how this could be racist. 'most non-english flamers i encounter in solo queue are chinese-speaking players' by itself is an observation.

racism would be to go on to say 'therefore, all chinese players are toxic assholes.'

The problem is that most of these threads don't come out of their way to be a discriminating asshole themselves, but their statements of their observations often imply the latter. And they always phrase in such a way that reeks passive provocation, making statements without clear or any clarification and justification, and pretty much always without a disclaimer.

Hell, OP even tried to link language barrier to in-game incompetency, which is completely off-topic to their own thread, and again without clarification and justification, just so that they could hopefully smear more mud into those people's faces and give them a pure negative spotlight some more.

I say the intent is really quite clear. If that's really not it, then I have to say OP needs some real work at expressing what they're trying to say in terms of writing.

The fact these kinds of threads come up once every couple days (most got deleted from getting completely out of hand, you know what I mean), pretending as if players with language barriers, toxic or otherwise, is the only problem in the community that needs a look at (let's not even mention the kind of obviously hateful and perhaps discriminating circlejerk in the comments that would frequently happen when threads like these appear), is already a massive issue in its own.

you can definitely infer meaning/intent from a statement, but to condemn or assume based off what you perceive as an implication is problematic. thought policing is an incredibly slippery slope but also wholly unnecessary to even approach.

i agree that the OP's wording is poor and he clearly could have worded his post to be more accommodating to conflicting viewpoints. however, the fact that he didn't doesn't represent a significant issue nor does the existence of this thread itself. it is entirely possible to discuss the prevalence of toxic non english speaking players in solo queue without devolving into dogmatic animosity. the onus is on the board moderators to remove rule breaking comments, not on the OP to account for the behaviour of internet strangers.

if anyone feels offended or triggered, then they may opt out of reading and participating in the thread. if they disagree, then they may present their own view. but until the OP explicitly violates board rules, there's no valid reason for his thread to be removed.

re: your anecdote - interesting, but not particularly relevant. wow and league are two games belonging to different genres; team-based competitive play exists in wow but does not represent the entirety of the game, while it constitutes the very core of league gameplay. league as a game is also far, far more frustrating.

yeah I deleted the anecdote very shortly after writing it up because I don't want to feel like I'm intentionally manipulating other people's emotion into agreeing with my stance through using personal reflections.

What I'm trying to say is that people are clearly blowing the "toxic non-English players" or "toxic Chinese players" out of proportion, given that the local community is equally just as bad if not really just worse. However we for some reason only come around to call out the former, and putting abnormal amount of effort into making it some kind of big problem that deserves everyone's attention when it clearly isn't one, at least not one that requires this degree of dedication when the other beast is entirely okay to be completely out in the wild.

Hell, a lot of people don't even have the slightest idea what the player with language barrier is even trying to say, or the real context behind what their words which may or may not be a real and hostile insult, how could we label them toxic and flamer often at first glance on the basis of differences alone? How could we treat them like things with uniform and fixed perks to be sorted and identified with a certain arbitrary label (negative ones at that) as opposed to being just another human being who may or may not be proficient in your language, and may or not may be a good person much like everyone else?

It's just a simple fairness problem in the end of the day really. Toxic players are just toxic players, the fact we start to label them and focus only on the portion of them with a certain label because idk, they are less relate-able so it's easier for one can go all out or something, is where the entirely thing becomes just wrong.

But yeah.

i agree, and i suspect it's part of the internalization of sorts by league players toward a negative chat atmosphere. people have become accustomed to a certain degree of flame/rage/passive aggressive behaviour - anyone who's played ranked for any length of time knows what to expect when their team is losing and tensions run high. it's almost accepted now that ranked and toxicity come as a package deal.

the bias stems from the fact that non english flame is comprehensible enough to be recognised as abusive, yet still unique enough to draw attention to itself as a separate existence. add to that the fact that the majority of non english flame happens to be in chinese, and you have yourself a recipe for leaving lasting impressions in people's memories whenever they get matched with a chinese flamer.

A vast majority of the toxic players I encounter are Chinese. It is not racist, it has been a trend that I have noticed over the past year and it is extremely frustrating. They are extremely rude; they tilt when the team falls behind/plays poorly, abuse teammates and afk/intentionally feed/troll the second someone tries to talk back to them. I also want to clarify that only most foreigner chinese players in OCE act like this, and ruin the reputation of chinese people in the League of Legends community.

I'd like to call myself an expert on identifying these individuals. A basic way of identifying such toxic and bad players is through this list I've gathered through my past experiences:
- Prevalent in Gold V - Diamond IV elo
- Very poor English speaking ability
- In-game names that don't make sense/are insensitive (JgYourMum, IUB Uzi, IIIlllIll, 13 06 1995, fkurmum) or a name that contains distinct chinese words (caomei, wocao, caonijie, nanjia)
- An overwhelming tendency to play chinese champions or champions with high raw-damage kits (Kled, Jarvan IV, Xin Zhao, Pantheon, Zed, Miss Fortune, Lee Sin, Nidalee, Annie, etc..)
- Negative attitude, tendency to talk about one's mother or father in a negative connotation, speaking chinese in chat, using common terms such as 'sb, cao ni ma, or ff20 gg noob team'
- Extremely aggressive in lane (they can crush their lane and snowball or get ganked, die 5 times in 4 minutes, tilt the entire team and potentially feed further or afk)
- ONLY build full damage and have no respect for team compositions. They play whoever they want.

I hope this comprehensive list acts as a general indicator for identifying these players. My basic recommendation is to simply mute them the second you get in game, and this applies to any other toxic player. General chat is a distraction and deters you from playing at your maximum potential. Or, just dodge queue the second you get one of these bad boys on your team.

Have a great day,
lmperius
PhD in Foreigner Chinese Player Studies in League of Legends Oceania

#Racism
* prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against someone of a different race based on the belief that one's own race is superior.

"The negativity bias, also known as the negativity effect, refers to the notion that, even when of equal intensity, things of a more negative nature (e.g. unpleasant thoughts, emotions, or social interactions; harmful/traumatic events) have a greater effect on one's psychological state and processes than do neutral or positive things."

What SEKAI says is true, your list of "identifying features" are not in any way specific to Chinese players, nor even specific to toxic players in general. 

"Most non-english speaking flamers are Chinese" is also a terribly biased statement, because the international population in Aus/OCE means that the vast majority of non or poor English speakers in OCE are Chinese simply by percentage, which has absolutely nothing to do with them being toxic. It's a matter of correlation, not causation, a very important distinction.

Rank also has absolutely ZERO relevance to this argument. It is not an argument of what item builds work when or of some gameplay mechanic, it is a player behaviour discussion. While there are some behaviours seen more prevalent in high elos (witch-hunting, toxic queue sniping) and the like, they are not exclusive, and this whole racism argument is not one of them. It is a flawed argument that exists at every level of play.
